text: And I'm preparing this for the Science Fiction Oral History Association. Of course, the oral history tapes on old times are important. But tomorrow morning, the events of today will be history. I still recall in 1920, when I was in the fifth grade, the feeling of wonder and shock with which we learned that the eighth graders upstairs were studying World War II from their history books. How could something we had just lived through be history? And I understand that there are people today feeling the same shock at finding that the 60s are any story of this. Well, out of the wisdom thus learned, I wish to give you this cassette of thoughts and statements of very recently. Mostly they are thoughts I presented at meetings of the Little Men's, which is to say the elves, gnomes, leprechauns, and little men's chowder, marching, and science fiction society, the source of the Invisible Little Men Award. The organization was named after the social club to which belonged Mr. O'Malley, Barnaby's fairy godfather, in the comic strip by Cockett Johnson in the days between World War II and McCarthyism. It ended then because Johnson was reported to have had a communist class. In the earliest days, the little man published the Rotomagnetic Digest, of which, I have been told, at least one complete set was still extant as recently as a year or two ago. But I wasn't one of the little men at that time. These thoughts are much more recent. There was the time, for instance, that I reviewed Paul Anserson's Home Brew, a collection of excellent short pieces of which perhaps the most brilliant is Uncleavie's True Thinking, in which he translates atomic theory into English. I had occasion to comment on his characterization of fascism on page 28 of the book. I noted that anyone living today should know that the packaging is not the contents and that the sales pitch is not the product. Furthermore, we do know what fascism is. Just as communism as attempts of people living under fewer regimes to move towards democracy and industrialization, fascism is an effort to stop a people's moves into democracy and to move them back to a medieval society. Of course, neither effort can be fully successful. Shortly after reviewing the book The Early Long, I had occasion to mention my earliest memory of a work by C. L. Moore. Since much of The Earliest Long and The Earliest More both appeared in Weird Tales, this was entirely appropriate. Those of you who have read The Early Long may remember that the earliest long was fairly representative of the usual contents of weird tales. No evoking of weirdness or horror, just an assertion of it. No real description, just an assertion of indescribableness. A heavy reliance on slime and filth and stench and immobilization. The murkiest of background hidden with the murkiest of prose. But don't get the idea that all of it was like that. There was some action prose and some true description. For me, the high point of that came in September of 1934. The East Bay Scientific Association was the local branch of the World Fan Organization, the International Scientific Association. We met at Aubrey McDermott's house that month, in fact, most months. My copy of Weird Tales hadn't come yet, but Aubrey's had. He handed it to me, opened, and said, Read that story. So I read it to him. It makes little difference whether we must or are condemned or are doomed, but it matters much whether we need to learn history or to learn from it, and whether history has lessons we must learn or simply contents from which we must draw our own learnings. Another instructor in my department has been known to ask his student why truth is better told by myths than by factual instruction, and this has relevance here. It is noteworthy that the truths learned from history are never embodied in our histories, but in our mythologies, which often then are reabsorbed into the histories in forms designed not to purvey but to hide the truth. However, my colleague's point has relevance here, although I do not know that he would share the truth as I see it. Pearl, for instance, often does not. The relevance lies in the essence of the difference between fact and truth. A fact is an idea or an understanding which corresponds to reality in the outside world. Truth is that which corresponds to our own conceptions of the universe. This is the appeal science fiction has for many of us, and also why many people find it weird. Often they prefer out-and-out fantasy, such as in normal mainstream fiction, which accords with the truths that normal zombies of our culture are supposed to accept. Even they know it to be unreal and escapist. And science fiction is no less so but at least we don't try to pretend it's real. Then we can use it to convey truths as well as to hide through facts. As Randall Garrett maintained that a past fan can mention at San Francisco Airport science fiction and mythologies have much in common. As I say, Pearl is a thoughtful man, and being a very domesticated man, he's undoubtedly writing his yearnings, which he shares with most of us, when he explores the gulf between wild and domesticated animals. And remember, domesticated doesn't necessarily mean tame. There's a saying that in the Galapagos Islands, the wild animals are tame and the tame animals are wild. If you want me to, I'll explain that. Pohl's explored the question before in a shorter Van Rijn story, saying that of two groups of aliens, one was domesticated and the other was wild animals. And Van Rijn pointed out that most of us are domesticated, but he and his group are wild animals. similar considerations are given in this book in an evolutionary point of view and he has one thing right evolutionary change always starts with a change of behaviour that is of habits and ecology but i don't like his terminology for his aliens in the benrhein story there wasn't enough information but for people like benrhein and like the rogovicki in the winter of the world we have very precise other terms which are better Wild animals are stocks which have never been domesticated. Animals which have had domesticated ancestors but are not now under domestication have very characteristic features, unlike true wild animals. We say they have gone wild, and the technical term is feral. Both the Van Rijn pack and the Rogoviki are described as feral. They are also described as pack predators, as opposed to being herd animals. By and large, pack predators operate from a home base, but are not truly territorial in the sense of fixed boundaries to their reign. For the little man's meeting of Friday, November 26, 1976, I gave a very short talk on the social science in science fiction. Of course, the first thing I did was to say it wasn't going to be limited to that. I told them that I had told Richard the leader of the meeting that I would say something on that subject, but when I started working on it I realized first that I would be more comfortable calling it science and behavioral sciences and science fiction because anthropology is both, and anthropology is how I think. Then second I realized that they are just not time for an organized presentation, so So I said I will refer you to Pamela Sargent's Introduction to Women of Wonder for a very good and very well organized presentation in one aspect of the field, which only has to be paraphrased to apply to several other aspects. I'll make some remarks about how the relationships are in general, not a review of specific stories, then I hope you'll all have questions to ask after I've said this. Actually, they did not have very many questions to ask. I think they were too anxious to go and socialize at the club they go to after meetings. So, I went on to say, by the standards of today, social and behavioral sciences are important in science fiction. Of course, they were always important, in that the way they were handled or not handled made the difference between a good story and a not-so-good story. Such elements are usually referred to as background, and character development, and plot handling, or plot the luck, and various other aspects of storytelling itself. And they were what makes 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea a supreme masterpiece, and Mysterious Island, its sequel, just a moderately good adventure to it. John Camel is often given credit for introducing them into science fiction, but they were certainly present in Food of the Gods and Tars Tarkas' Revolution, Antharchian Morals, to say nothing of Ralph 1. Du Forseffro and Bliss. The reason Camel gets such credit is mostly because so many writers remember that Camel was paying a cent a word and sometimes two cents for stories which had some of these features, while Fred Pohl and his fellow unfortunates on other pulps were paying from a fifth to half a cent for stories that didn't. What they don't stop to think about is that Campbell knew about these things because Harry Bates, paying two cents a word, and F. Orland Tremaine paying one cent, had previously demanded it of Campbell. You may object that most of John Campbell Jr.'s own stories didn't have much in the way of character development, but each of them did have something in the field of social or behavioral science, even if social and behavioral scientists might disagree with what he did. The readers didn't want any better. As a matter of fact, they mostly agreed with him. The difference now is that with people like Ursula Le Guin and McCaffrey writing, the standards for treatment of social and behavioral sciences and science fiction should now be at a higher level than the personal prejudices of John Campbell and Ben Bova, or, for that matter, Jerry Brunel. There are certain things we do know about people. We know that people tend to act in what they consider to be their own best interests. And we know that this includes being able afterwards to live with their consciences. We know that people tend to want to reciprocate what they get from others. This includes revenge as much as it includes paying other obligations. We know that, on the other hand, that people tend to want to take things which are denied to them, but that they can be taught not to do this. We know that some people are capable of great cruelty to others, and that other people raised in much the same cultures do not approve of this. There are many different kinds of behavior which anthropologists refer to as war, but some peoples do not have any such behaviors, and many people refuse to take part in them. Many people write and talk about aggressive drives, but one thing we do know is that aggression is not a separate drive, but that the word is a cover term for various behaviors engaged in for various reasons when, but not always when, any drive or desire is interfered with it. We also know that such aggressive urge can be inhibited and then may or may not turn against other targets, from the person himself to perfect strangers seen only at a distance. People who live in excessively polite cultures tend to be excessively vicious in wars or in personal killings. We know that the basic relationships between people are power-mediated relationships, and that power, and hence aggressiveness, is behavior related to control of access to resources. We know that dominance and submission are power relations and hence also involve such control and lack of control, but that also dominance is itself a very prized resource, since a resource is anything anyone needs or wants or can be fond into thinking he should try for. The various commodities, for instance, which are offered by those who conduct our practices of religion, are at times, and for many people, very valuable resources. Information is a most important resource, and those who control access to it can be very powerful. It should be noted that often, the actual practitioners in its supply do not control either the access or the supply. In our culture, this is what advertising and publishing are concerned with. Because social relationships are power relationships, and the resources required and available depend on the technology, and not only the technological level, but the technological biases of the states of the arts, technology is very important to social organization. However, rapid technological change may not bring social changes so rapidly. The various fascist movements, for instance were efforts to reestablish feudal social relationships in a period of industrial capitalism And as Milavon Giles pointed out in the book that got him in jail the first time the communist and socialist revolutions were efforts to establish industrial technology in countries whose prevailing social structures were still feudal and colonial For these reasons, plus those mentioned by James Gunn in This Fortress World I'm very leery of stellar empires, though Van Vogt had a rather plausible possibility in the weapons shop universe. Doc Smith's civilization is even more convincing. As to Bliche's fascist future, and I've already mentioned why not, the substrate culture is now gone. To make a good story, you have to create tensions in the reader. Violence is a most inadequate way to do this, and besides, it creates in the reader or viewer the erroneous belief that violence is fun and that violence solves problems. Also, as Ben Bovo points out in Notes to a science fiction writer, slam-bang action is not what we mean by conflict. In science fiction, the main conflicts, that is to say, the tension-producing situations, are simply culture shock and future shock, especially the explorations of extrapolations like Age Gold encourages writers to do for Galaxy and the various worlds created, for instance, by Ursula Le Guin. These are wholly social and behavioral problems within the spectator himself being operated upon by what he sees in the story. One thing I liked very much about John Campbell's A Post to Stories was his violation of one rule of American storytelling. Our culture places great emphasis on failure. The object of competition and testing is not to produce winners, is to produce losers. And thus, a general rule of our fiction is that a protagonist has to go through a cycle of degradation. He's not allowed to win until he's had a few failures. John Camel wasn't interested in this. He was interested in winners. His writers couldn't always go along with him, so he printed a lot of degradation cycle stories, but he didn't insist on it as most editors do. Anthropology is the social and behavioral science that deals with groups of people. but that still deals with them not only as people, but as whole human beings. That is why the very best science fiction has a lot of ethnography in it, because ethnography is the branch of anthropology which deals with societies and cultures as the beliefs and activities of individual human beings living together as organized groups. Doc Smith was a master at this, and he did it so well that most people don't realize he was doing it. Naturally, there's lots more I could say. but some of you may have questions, and the rest of you probably want to get out of here. They did. Also at that time, I prepared a comment on the election debates for my anthropology classes. In the first debate, I told them, Mr. Ford charged that Jimmy Carter's successor, the present governor of Georgia, had told Ford that the Medicare setup in Georgia was a shambles, and that therefore Carter wasn't much of an administrator. The poor klutz didn't even realize that Medicare is a federal program and that it's a scandal all over the United States and that the governor was not complaining about Carter as an administrator, but about Ford. The governor, that is, the current governor of Georgia, did try to set the record straight the next day, but it got very brief mention in the media and hasn't been picked up by the Carter campaign either. Carter, on the other hand, noted the need for a national health program and that there were poor people he knows in his plains who had very great difficulty getting any medical care. but carter did not it would never occur to him to realize there might be an intimate relationship between the poverty of those friends of his and the fact that the carter family owns five and a half billion dollars worth of property and business none of which could exist without the presence of a reservoir of low paid mostly seasonal rural labor the whole little agribusiness setup he has is completely dependent on him if they were his slaves he would recognize his need responsibility and would have health care for them just as he has mechanics for his machinery and calls them veterinarians for his livestock. But for over a century, no one has admitted that there is slavery in America, so his responsibility is reduced to a tug at his heartstrings and an effort to shift the burden from the county hospital and the local property tax to the federal government, so we can have a Medicare shambles for everyone and not just for folks who were 365, who have Social Security. Now that, of course, doesn't at first glance look like science fiction, but at least, it's a footnote in preparation for reading some, say, of James Gunn's medical future. In the prefatory note to the story of the three-cornered wheel in his book, The Trouble Twisters, he quoted a Vance Hall that, and the quotation is, man, the child of earth, lives by certain principles which are immutable, end quote. These are there given as Parkinson's First and Second Laws, Sturgeon's Revelation, Murphy's Law, and a fourth law of thermodynamics. This latter, in my estimation, is merely a way of stating the law of entropy. And it seems also that Parkinson's first law only applies to humans within the orbit of civilization. That law, for folks touched by civilization, which is to say affected by exploitation, and the others, in some degree for all folk, are human ways of making entropy, but they're far from being immutable. They're highly variable, both in degree and in manifestation, though they do touch most of the laws for all people, and Parkinson's first law only for those in civilization. Two years ago at Oakland, and i understand some other cons around that time there was a panel of writers talking about the military mind and how misunderstood it was by many people um it occurred to me that it was possible there might be such a panel at vancouver so I wrote to them and said that it was almost impossible to answer these people from the floor but if there was such a panel I would like to be on it so I could give some words of true wisdom from the table instead of fighting for a spot from the floor well I haven't heard from them so I don't think that I will be on any such panel but I did prepare some remarks. After all, I didn't know how much time I would have so I boiled my absolutely minimal essential presentation of about 4 hours. I boiled down to about 5 minutes and 10 seconds. I was going to start with a reference to the West Coast maneuvers of July 1941, before the United States was officially in World War II. There were two armies, one of regular Army units and one of former National Guard outfits, with the rules made so the regulars couldn't possibly lose. They were losing, so the rules were changed to favor them still more. And again. Finally, the whole thing was called off a week early, just before the final debacle. You see, all during peacetime, the War College keeps the regular Army officers trained about what to do when war comes. The National Guard officers get some of this, but they don't take it all that seriously, because they have to spend most of their time living in the real world, something the regular officers don't know much about. There was one guy in my regiment who did take it seriously. the security officer. The others didn't take him seriously, but they should have. He was what it was all about. Well, we're right. We do make cracks about the military in Martin. And we don't see that much difference between military occupation troops in so-called peace and the conquest troops in war. Oh, the bodies are prettier. They shave and bathe more often. in almost all societies the organization of fighters for war parallels that of men's work groups in fact they often have the same personnel but in our society and I include here the Soviets the organization of the military is like the social organization which preceded ours the kind of society we refer to as feudal or semi-feudal the peasant-based societies organized into patron-cliant sets, where patrons are to make the decisions and clients are first to be exploited and second to be hoarded. And to put up with that, they have to be specially indoctrinated. As Auburn McDermott reminded us from the audience at Oakland, four hundred years and more ago, the people did not think the way we did. Our type of civilian mind was then just beginning to rise to contest the hitherto unchallenged rule of the military mind. and then I was going to ask if anyone in the audience knows the purpose of close order drill the Russians once tried to abolish close order drill and they found that they had no army L. Ron Hubbard who wrote Fear and Typewriter in the Sky and that masterpiece Final Blackout and Ordok Methuselah stories was in the military he was a navy commander and one of his basic teachings is that all authority rests upon the ability to move people about physically in space. So, I was going to say, I'll put this in terms that at least the Scientologists here will be able to understand. Close order drill is an opening procedure drill to reduce com lag between the time an order is received and the time it's carried out. So I'll just go there, do that, stop it, do something else, go somewhere else. You see the close order drill and you see the opening procedure drill. It's simply to condition you to take orders without stopping to think about it. The difference is that Scientology later teaches you how to make up your own orders and give them to yourself. And the military never willingly lets you go. You wind up being a wind-up toy. Programmed to their ideas. and you start wondering why these crazy civilians won't just bend over and do what you think they should. And that is why we make such remarks about the military mind. Now, I could go on with this, but I'll sum it up. The purpose of the military is not to die for one's country. It's not even to make the enemy die for his country. It is to make the enemy live for one's own country. That means to destroy the enemy as an independent organization. In other words, the purpose of the military is conquest, which is to say, the increase of one's own client's set and its perpetuation. And if you want a course in the anthropology of peasant base, military administered patron client societies, I'll be around. So, it occurs to me that some of the people on that panel awed me. I wasn't used to the helpless inadequate feeling I got when I heard them on this subject. The nearest I can recall is the way I used to feel around a certain corporal soon after I was first drafted into the U.S. Army. And since it's an example that shows the nature of some aspects of this particular military mind, let me tell you. He was a little big for his age So he lied about his years and joined the National Guard when he was in high school And they double-crossed him and started getting ready for war His outfit had been activated in October 1940 So by the time I was drafted in February 1941 He already had four months of a nasty, muddy Puget Sound winter under his bed They'd gotten some training between raindrops and now they were a training cadre and he was a corporal and they were supposed to pass what they'd found on gas. Well, nothing's perfect so now and then I'd have to ask a question and even very seldom make a suggestion like, if we're going to be digging all these holes wouldn't it make sense first to set aside the turf from where the hole and the pile of dirt are going to be and then afterward lay it over the dirt so it won't be quite so obvious just where the holes are? You know, I wasn't trying to show up to the trainers. It's just that I wanted my fellow draftees to have at least a minimum chance of survival if it came to that. Besides, I'm selfish, and the more survivor types I have around me, the better chance I have of surviving among them. Well, this corporal was one of the snottiest of snot-willed kids. You understand, he wasn't dumb. He really had great potential. It's just that he thought he was already there. He was on the same floor of the same barracks as the squad I was in. Thank God he wasn't my corporal. I had a real good corporal. I really loved having that. But the kid embarked on a real deliberate campaign to humiliate me. Well, I was living it. Only one day I was over in the rec room writing a letter. Naturally, I got a table as far back as possible along one wall so I could see everything, especially who came in and went out the door. Then a bunch of kids came in, including the corporals. They had an older sergeant with me. He was from another outfit, and I'd never seen him before, but I noticed they held him in very hard regard, and he had a forest green braid on his sleeve, which meant that in a previous military incarnation he'd been an officer. They took seats in the corner behind me, and I wasn't paying any attention, after all it was none of my goodness, but suddenly the corporal's voice rose above the level of the conversation, and he said, The worst kind of bullet is ricochet. Ricochet. You know. Whang! Well, I don't know what possessed me to butt in, but I turned around and said, The worst kind of bullet is a spent bullet. It drifts along. Hunting. The sergeant got very excited. He said, You've been in action. Where were you? And I said, Hmm? You were in action. Where was it? And just about the time I began to get back control of my lower jaw, the corporal began to realize what was happening, and he lost control of his. Well, I wish I could say that after that he was a changed character, but he wasn't. It's just that he was no longer carrying on a deliberate campaign. But you see what I mean about a hopeless, helpless inadequacy. How do you educate brilliant but ignorant people who already know everything? Now I want you to understand though That the corporal's attitude Was completely characteristic of the military mind And it's documented by numerous studies Of patron client societies It's especially found in situations Where the respective ranks Do not very much differ People who are clearly of patron grade Have much more effective ways To keep clients aware of the fact People with just a little authority Have to keep fighting for it and the methods they use are born of desperation. The fact that I didn't want his job was immaterial. I was obviously going to be one of the first new TFCs, and he was the youngest old corporal. To the militarized mind, he was in dire danger. I was also hoping that someone would pick up on that remark I made about the security officer being what it was all about, and would ask me from the audience what I meant. I had an answer to that, too. The answer is this. You've heard it said that our army is always ready for the last previous war it was in. In 1941, we were going to fight against Hitler's conquest of the German people and in France and the Low Countries and Norway, also against the Japanese conquests and those of Mussolini. The last war our military was in at that time had not been against Germany in World War I, but the interventions through Archangel and Vladivostok and in the Baltic States, and they've never forgiven the rest of us for the war we actually had them fight in the 1940s. We formed the East Bay Scientific Association, and the name would never change, even after we had members in San Francisco. I know it lasted until at least 1935, and maybe later. Aubrey says it must have been started in 1928, because he has something about it in my handwriting, dated 1928, and it now. I know it had to be after the parent organization became International Scientific Association, because we copied that name. I'm also very sure it had to be 1930, because I recall it was just after I'd come home after shipping on the tanker district of Columbia, and enrolled in the University of California summer session, and that was 1930. After the international organization was founded, Bernsbeck had one of his cover picture story contests. I think it was the first one, maybe the only one from Amazing. I toyed with trying to write a story to enter, but Ray Palmer wrote one and won. I believe the prize money was $100. He used it to buy the organization a mimeograph and put out a club or a cosmology. You could get quite a mimeograph for $100 in those days. Anyway, from then on, the president was also editor. By 1932, Aubrey was president and editor, and I was secretary and assistant editor. In passing through two or three hands, something had happened to the mimeograph. What we'd received from past President Eaton in Atlanta was not a machine. Eaton swore it was just what he had received from his predecessor. The mimeograph drum was flattened out to about a quarter circle, a flat deck was laid over it, and a handle put in the middle of the deck. This you held and leaned on while rolling the drum and stencil the length of the sheet of paper. I've seen them since for postcard size, but that's the only one I ever saw for eight-and-a-half-by-eleven paper. I saw quite too much of it. Aubrey saw more. I left in August 1932 to go to be graduate assistant in anthropology at the University of Nebraska. I stopped to see some members in Oregon and Washington and hitchhiked to Milwaukee where I made the same mistake with Ray that Aubrey made with me. The first thought I had when he opened the door was, my gosh, he didn't tell me his younger brother was hunchbacked too. All the time I was there, Ray was warning me about the people I'd be staying with in Chicago. Walter Dennis was founder and president of the Chicago Club. Ray had visited and told me, Dennis' mother was German and said, Great store of good food and would keep insisting I have more at meals and forcing it on me. Actually, I didn't see anything unusual, and nobody forced anything on me. The Chicago club was actually not very active fannishly. They had founded an astronomy club based on the then quite new Adler Planetarium, and the astronomy club had sort of swallowed the fan club. Ray had also mentioned our one member In Lincoln where I was going It was one of our few girl or young woman Members and it seemed some of Ray's Letters had been rather glowing Incidentally just as I Always sign my name C-H-A Small letter H and small letter A Ray always used Rack Small A and small P I think we both started that Before either of us wrote to the other I asked my lift into Lincoln how to get to the fan's address. Why, that sounds like it's down in Russian town, he said, making it plain no one would want to go or know anyone down there. It seemed everyone down there spoke German. As a matter of fact, there were in that part of town many people from Russia being volt of Germans, like many of the loggers on the northern California and the vecino coast, who were Russian Finns. Well, I found the place. It wasn't well. It seems she was recently married, and her husband had seen at least one of Ray's letters. Ray had known it, as she had written to ask him not to send any more. I can't recall whether I shaved off my beard at Milwaukee or after I got to Lincoln. Dr. Myles J. Brewer also lived at Lincoln. His office was in the building a block and a half from where I got a room. I never did see it. His receptionist evidently didn't approve of science fiction and let me know I was unwelcome. Christmas vacation, I went to Boston to visit the other local fan club We believe that it was older than the Chicago one But probably not as old as East Bay At some time, briefly, there seems to have been one in New York City But just when, I don't know Maybe Kanye Ruppert might know He put out Science Fiction Digest And I spent a couple of days with him He lived in South Ozone Park then In one of those hyphenated Queen's addresses a lot of others around Boston I visited as I recall one of the Oregon members named Ockerman possibly with two N's who was going to MIT he was in nuclear chemistry there were very few of them now I guess they're all absorbed into nuclear physics that winter or the next one at I believe Washington University near St. Louis L. Ron Hubbard and John Campbell Jr. were taking the very first class ever given called nuclear physics During his Dianetics period Camel announced that he had discovered that ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny was a very important engrammic phrase behind his mind and he couldn't understand why it should be so strong in the mind of a physical scientist Then he remembered that he grew up in the household of a biologist But he seems never to have made the connection between the above facts and his lifelong dedication to the proposition many cultural phenomena are of genetic origin Incidentally, the weather that winter was very cold and deep snows hit just before I started. I couldn't hitchhike. I went by freight to Elizabeth, New Jersey and by a bus from New York City to Boston and back, then freight's back to Lincoln. After that storm, Ray wrote, the east wind blew off the frozen lake and made it even colder in Milwaukee. He took pitchers of hot water to the second floor window, poured them out in front of people coming along. The outside of the water would freeze on the way down, shatter against the wall, and a cloud of steam would rise up in front of him. On the other hand, how much of that ray wrote me as true is questionable. Other people say he wrote them different accounts of his life at that time. To change the subject completely, Spider Robinson's recent column on Books by Women inspired me to write him quite a letter. one of the points I made to him was that I couldn't understand why it took him so long to accumulate all those books because most of them were old books. Even considering how long it takes to get something published in amazing. However, since I wrote him the letter, I've been thinking more about women writers of science fiction. And it's true. there have always been women writers of science fiction there have always been very good women writers of science fiction the point is there have not been the cloud of mediocre women science fiction writers as there has been a cloud of mediocre men science fiction writers regardless of whether they use their own names or their initials or a fake name, still, for a woman to break into science fiction writing, she had to be real good. And then, of course, there's the recent June 1977 women's issue of Analog. He said, Ben Bovitt said, that he could not get women artists. it's very strange at the same time this thing was on the stands there was an issue of Galaxy on the stands with a cover and interior work by Bonnie Dalzell and oddly enough her work for that galaxy was very very similar to the cover art and inside work that appeared by a man on the women's issue of Analog totally unlike other, and to my eyes better, work by Bonnie Dalzell. And by the way, did you see the AP wire photo of the Prudhoe Bay control room for the Alaska Pipeline? I swear, those two hard hats sitting there are aliens, or maybe one of them is only half-alien. The names are Margus, M-A-R-G-I-S, Freichtel. F-R-E-I-C-H-T-L. And the other one is named Dave Funtempt. F-U-N-T-E-M-P-T. Surely those are not Earth names. Maybe they were devised by Jack Vance. Maybe.

segments.text: And I'm preparing this for the Science Fiction Oral History Association.
Of course, the oral history tapes on old times are important.
But tomorrow morning, the events of today will be history.
I still recall in 1920, when I was in the fifth grade,
the feeling of wonder and shock with which we learned that the eighth graders upstairs
were studying World War II from their history books.
How could something we had just lived through be history?
And I understand that there are people today feeling the same shock at finding that the 60s are any story of this.
Well, out of the wisdom thus learned, I wish to give you this cassette of thoughts and statements of very recently.
Mostly they are thoughts I presented at meetings of the Little Men's, which is to say the elves, gnomes, leprechauns,
and little men's chowder, marching, and science fiction society, the source of the Invisible Little Men Award.
The organization was named after the social club to which belonged Mr. O'Malley,
Barnaby's fairy godfather, in the comic strip by Cockett Johnson
in the days between World War II and McCarthyism.
It ended then because Johnson was reported to have had a communist class.
In the earliest days, the little man published the Rotomagnetic Digest,
of which, I have been told, at least one complete set was still extant
as recently as a year or two ago.

But I wasn't one of the little men at that time. These thoughts are much more recent. There was the time, for instance, that I reviewed Paul Anserson's Home Brew, a collection of excellent short pieces of which perhaps the most brilliant is Uncleavie's True Thinking, in which he translates atomic theory into English.
I had occasion to comment on his characterization of fascism on page 28 of the book.
I noted that anyone living today should know that the packaging is not the contents
and that the sales pitch is not the product.
Furthermore, we do know what fascism is.
Just as communism as attempts of people living under fewer regimes
to move towards democracy and industrialization,
fascism is an effort to stop a people's moves into democracy
and to move them back to a medieval society.
Of course, neither effort can be fully successful.
Shortly after reviewing the book The Early Long,

this was entirely appropriate.
Those of you who have read The Early Long
may remember that the earliest long
was fairly representative of the usual contents of weird tales.
No evoking of weirdness or horror,
just an assertion of it.
No real description,
just an assertion of indescribableness.
A heavy reliance on slime and filth
and stench and immobilization.
The murkiest of background
hidden with the murkiest of prose.
But don't get the idea that all of it was like that.
There was some action prose
and some true description.
For me, the high point of that came in September of 1934.

the International Scientific Association.

There is considerable difference of content here.
It makes little difference whether we must or are condemned or are doomed,
but it matters much whether we need to learn history or to learn from it,
and whether history has lessons we must learn
or simply contents from which we must draw our own learnings.
Another instructor in my department has been known to ask his student
why truth is better told by myths than by factual instruction,
and this has relevance here.

It is noteworthy that the truths learned from history are never embodied in our histories, but in our mythologies, which often then are reabsorbed into the histories in forms designed not to purvey but to hide the truth.
However, my colleague's point has relevance here, although I do not know that he would share the truth as I see it.
Pearl, for instance, often does not.
The relevance lies in the essence of the difference between fact and truth.
A fact is an idea or an understanding which corresponds to reality in the outside world.
Truth is that which corresponds to our own conceptions of the universe.
This is the appeal science fiction has for many of us, and also why many people find it weird.
Often they prefer out-and-out fantasy, such as in normal mainstream fiction,
which accords with the truths that normal zombies of our culture are supposed to accept.
Even they know it to be unreal and escapist.
And science fiction is no less so
but at least we don't try to pretend it's real.
Then we can use it to convey truths
as well as to hide through facts.

that a past fan can mention

For the little man's meeting of Friday, November 26, 1976,
I gave a very short talk on the social science in science fiction.
Of course, the first thing I did was to say it wasn't going to be limited to that.
I told them that I had told Richard the leader of the meeting that I would say something
on that subject, but when I started working on it I realized first that I would be more
comfortable calling it science and behavioral sciences and science fiction because anthropology
is both, and anthropology is how I think.
Then second I realized that they are just not time for an organized presentation, so
So I said I will refer you to Pamela Sargent's Introduction to Women of Wonder for a very
good and very well organized presentation in one aspect of the field, which only has
to be paraphrased to apply to several other aspects.
I'll make some remarks about how the relationships are in general, not a review of specific
stories, then I hope you'll all have questions to ask after I've said this.
Actually, they did not have very many questions to ask.
I think they were too anxious to go and socialize
at the club they go to after meetings.
So, I went on to say,
by the standards of today,
social and behavioral sciences are important in science fiction.
Of course, they were always important,
in that the way they were handled or not handled
made the difference between a good story and a not-so-good story.
Such elements are usually referred to as
background, and character development,
and plot handling, or plot the luck,
and various other aspects of storytelling itself.
And they were what makes 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea
a supreme masterpiece,
and Mysterious Island, its sequel,
just a moderately good adventure to it.
John Camel is often given credit
for introducing them into science fiction,
but they were certainly present in Food of the Gods
and Tars Tarkas' Revolution, Antharchian Morals,
to say nothing of Ralph 1. Du Forseffro and Bliss.

The reason Camel gets such credit is mostly because so many writers remember that Camel was paying a cent a word and sometimes two cents for stories which had some of these features, while Fred Pohl and his fellow unfortunates on other pulps were paying from a fifth to half a cent for stories that didn't.
What they don't stop to think about is that Campbell knew about these things
because Harry Bates, paying two cents a word,
and F. Orland Tremaine paying one cent,
had previously demanded it of Campbell.
You may object that most of John Campbell Jr.'s own stories
didn't have much in the way of character development,
but each of them did have something in the field of social or behavioral science,
even if social and behavioral scientists might disagree with what he did.
The readers didn't want any better.
As a matter of fact, they mostly agreed with him.
The difference now is that with people like Ursula Le Guin and McCaffrey writing,
the standards for treatment of social and behavioral sciences and science fiction
should now be at a higher level than the personal prejudices of John Campbell and Ben Bova,
or, for that matter, Jerry Brunel.
There are certain things we do know about people.
We know that people tend to act in what they consider to be their own best interests.
And we know that this includes being able afterwards to live with their consciences.
We know that people tend to want to reciprocate what they get from others.
This includes revenge as much as it includes paying other obligations.
We know that, on the other hand, that people tend to want to take things which are denied to them,
but that they can be taught not to do this.
We know that some people are capable of great cruelty to others,
and that other people raised in much the same cultures do not approve of this.
There are many different kinds of behavior which anthropologists refer to as war,
but some peoples do not have any such behaviors,
and many people refuse to take part in them.
Many people write and talk about aggressive drives,
but one thing we do know is that aggression is not a separate drive,
but that the word is a cover term for various behaviors engaged in for various reasons
when, but not always when, any drive or desire is interfered with it.
We also know that such aggressive urge can be inhibited
and then may or may not turn against other targets,
from the person himself to perfect strangers seen only at a distance.
People who live in excessively polite cultures tend to be excessively vicious in wars or in personal killings.
We know that the basic relationships between people
are power-mediated relationships,
and that power, and hence aggressiveness,
is behavior related to control of access to resources.
We know that dominance and submission are power relations
and hence also involve such control and lack of control,
but that also dominance is itself a very prized resource,
since a resource is anything anyone needs or wants
or can be fond into thinking he should try for.
The various commodities, for instance, which are offered by those who conduct our practices of religion,
are at times, and for many people, very valuable resources.
Information is a most important resource, and those who control access to it can be very powerful.
It should be noted that often, the actual practitioners in its supply
do not control either the access or the supply.
In our culture, this is what advertising and publishing are concerned with.
Because social relationships are power relationships, and the resources required and available depend on the technology,
and not only the technological level, but the technological biases of the states of the arts,
technology is very important to social organization.
However, rapid technological change may not bring social changes so rapidly.
The various fascist movements, for instance
were efforts to reestablish feudal social relationships
in a period of industrial capitalism
And as Milavon Giles pointed out in the book
that got him in jail the first time
the communist and socialist revolutions were efforts
to establish industrial technology
in countries whose prevailing social structures
were still feudal and colonial

To make a good story,
you have to create tensions in the reader.

the erroneous belief that violence is fun and that violence solves problems.
Also, as Ben Bovo points out in Notes to a science fiction writer,
slam-bang action is not what we mean by conflict.
In science fiction, the main conflicts, that is to say, the tension-producing situations,
are simply culture shock and future shock,
especially the explorations of extrapolations like Age Gold encourages writers to do for Galaxy
and the various worlds created, for instance, by Ursula Le Guin.
These are wholly social and behavioral problems within the spectator himself
being operated upon by what he sees in the story.
One thing I liked very much about John Campbell's A Post to Stories
was his violation of one rule of American storytelling.
Our culture places great emphasis on failure.
The object of competition and testing is not to produce winners,
is to produce losers.
And thus, a general rule of our fiction is
that a protagonist has to go through
a cycle of degradation.
He's not allowed to win
until he's had a few failures.
John Camel wasn't interested in this.
He was interested in winners.
His writers couldn't always go along with him,
so he printed a lot of degradation cycle stories,
but he didn't insist on it
as most editors do.
Anthropology is the social and behavioral science
that deals with groups of people.
but that still deals with them not only as people, but as whole human beings.
That is why the very best science fiction has a lot of ethnography in it,
because ethnography is the branch of anthropology which deals with societies and cultures
as the beliefs and activities of individual human beings living together as organized groups.
Doc Smith was a master at this, and he did it so well that most people don't realize he was doing it.
